definition:
(Particle). 1. introductory exclamation like English
Oh or Well.
2. miki-a ‘to say “ah”’.
3. grammatical functor marking attribution.
(N.) the abaca plant, fiber, or cloth.

(V.) mayabak, mayayabak, meyabak; to do
something until morning; become morning.
(N.) morning.

(V.) bother, worry. [usually distributive:
mangabala’, as in: e ka mangabala. ‘Don’t worry’].

(V.) makiyabe ‘accompany’; mi-abeyabe ‘live
together, stay together’,
(N.) friend, companion [used as a term of
address], kayabe ‘companion’; pa:makiya’be ‘the
skill of making and keeping friends’.

(V.) -an: ‘to warn someone’; ma-‘to be warned’;
payabi’su ‘have someone warned’; i-‘take
something as a warning’.
(N.) warning; subpoena; ma:nabi’su ‘one who
warns’.

(V.) -an ‘to return something’; imitate. maki- -an ‘to
answer back, retort’, mablas, minablas,
paki-qablas, payablasan, inablas, ayablas,
makayablas, meyablas, pamanablas, pekaqablas.
(N.) what one gives in return for something else.
echo; revenge. kakablas ‘echo’.

(V.) man- ‘to fertilize’; pa-‘have something
fertilized’; maki-, paki-‘share fertilizer’.

(V.) in–an, mi–an ‘be swarmed on by tiny insects
called absang’,
(N.) gnat, fruitfly (?)–a very small insect.

(V.) magpaka-‘eat one’s fill’. See qabsiq.
(D.) satisfied (with respect to hunger).

(V.) pag–an ‘submit something to lawyers’.
magqabugadu, see qabugadu.
(N.) lawyer.

(V.) -an [abuluran] ‘to de-rib (to remove the center
rib from a leaf)’, ‘to put a crease in’.

(V.) man-, pa-‘abuse, take unfair advantage’.
(D.) ma-.
(N.) one who takes unfair advantage; ka- -an,
kapana-.

(V.) ‘reach’, ‘hand something to someone’.
‘understand’: E ku pa ayabutan. ‘I can’t grasp the
meaning yet’.

(N.) milled rice. maga:qabyas ‘rice dealer’
[bigasera–from Tagalog, is also used].

(V.) -an ‘to put something on a spit’; pa- ‘to have
something spitted’.
(D.) ma-‘to be spitted’.
(N.) a spit, made of bamboo, for barbecuing.

(N.) explosion.
pa:pakbu’ng ‘a toy gun or bamboo piston device
used to make fruit seeds shoot out–like a pop-gun;
or a nail-and-tube device for exploding caps’.
2

(V.) manga-[distributive] have an accident.
(D.) mayaksidenti ‘be hurt in an accident’.
(N.) accident.

(V.) -an ‘to grate, scrape’.
(N.) adjaran-ungut ‘coconut-grating stool’; see
kudkuran.
pipagadjaran ‘place for scraping’.

(V.) mang- ‘pray’ (intransitive). pa:ng- ‘pray for
something’; maki-‘pray together’; pakipang- ‘pray
together for…’.

(V.) pangaladwan ‘do something a second time’.
(Nu.) two.
kakadwaq ‘second’; pangalawaq ‘the second one
(e.g. child)’.

(V.) summon, invite, signal. man-, -an, pa-, pan-.
(D.) may-‘be invited’.
(N.) pa:managkat ‘manner of inviting’.

(V.) harvest, gather.
ma:magtal, agtala’n, papayagtal, manayagtal.
(N.) pa:nagtal ‘the harvest’; pi:panagtala’n ‘place
of harvest’.

(N.) accident.
(V.) manga-[distributive] ‘have an accident’.
(D.) mayaksidenti ‘be hurt in an accident’.

(V.) associate. maki-a’gum ‘join a group’,
(N.) a:gu’man ‘an association’. kagum ‘associate, a
concomitant’.

(N.) current.
(V.) mamagus, minagus ‘flow’. papa-agus-an ‘cause
to flow’.
(N.) a medicinal liquid used to clean wounds.

(N.) cold sore.
(V.) [stative] miyagyapan ‘have cold sore’; [stat.
distributive] manga-agyap-an.

(N.) ala’lan ‘election’, pa:manala’l ‘manner of
electing’; pipagalalan ‘polling place’.
(V.) man-. mangayalal ‘elect repeatedly’;
papa-yalal ‘get someone elected’; ke:ala’l ‘cause
election’.
(D.) mayalal ‘be elected’.

(N.) ala’le ‘care’.
alalayan ‘a prop, support’.
(V.) alalayan ‘support, maintain something’;
magkala:kalale ‘beware of’.
(D.) malale ‘careful (e.g. speech)’.

(N.) wire. ala’mbring suksukan ‘barbed wire’.
(D.) mayalambre ‘be caught on a wire’.

1. in combination with numbers, as alas singko
‘five o’clock’.
2. bungang ala’s ‘heat-rash’.
3. ala’s ‘ace (in card-playing)’.

(N.) place where the sun sets.
(St.) mi-albug-an ‘be caught by nightfall’.
(N., V.) noise, make noise; see qalburutu.

(N.) sun; day. ganing-aldo ‘pre-dawn morning’,
kayaldawanan ‘birthday; anniversary’.
(D.) aldo-aldo ‘daily’.

(N.) dust.
(D.) maqalikabuk ‘dusty’; mi:alika-buka’n ‘covered
with dust’; makaqa-likabuk [St.] ‘dusty’.
(V.) ma:n-alikabuk ‘raising dust’.

(N.) a person who acts skillfully, lively.
pangaqalistu ‘acting skillfully’.
(D.) kaqalistuwan; kasingalistu; pekaqalistu.

(N./D.) other.
pami-aliwaq ‘difference’; pamanaliwaq ‘process of
change’.
(D.) maqaliwa:liwaq ‘all sorts of’; miyayaliwaq
‘disparate’; mi-aliwaq ‘different’.
(V.) man-aliwaq ‘change something’; i-aliwaq
‘change something’.

(N.) thunder; (?lightning?); see duldul.
Usually this word is used in curses, as: dipaning
alti!

(N.) 1. eaves and drain of a roof; [metaphorically]
‘heavy drinking’.
2. shins.
(D.) meyalulud ‘barked shins’.

(N.) aluminum; cheap money (new coins–as
contrasted to the older coins with more silver
content).

(N.) contribution. peka-ambag ‘thing given’.
(V.) [intransitive] man-ambag, pan-ambag,
makapanambag. [transitive] i-ambag, ayambag,
ayam-bagan, panambaga, ka-ambagan, pa-ambag,
apayambagan.

(N.) dew.
(V.) mamambun ‘be about to rain’.
(D.) mayambun ‘overcast, misty’; miyambunan
‘covered with dew’.

(V.) borrow; see -dam-. manamdam,
mangayamdam, pakiyamdam, makiyamdam,
makayamdam, a:yamdam.

(N.) winter, the cold season from October to
January.

(N.) mosquito.
(V.) amuk-an ‘be bitten by mosquitoes’.
(D.) mayamuk ‘be full of mosquitoes (place)’.
(N.) a kind of grass or weed with pronged seeds.

(N.) child; (pl.) a:nak.
anak-anakan ‘adopted child’; ina:yinak
‘godchildren’; pekayanak ‘substitute for a child’;
anak-bastardo, anak-banggera, anak-puta,
anak-lele-kwayan, anak-lalam-tete ‘illegitimate
child’,
(V.) mang-anak ‘give birth’, maka-anak ‘capable of
giving birth’.
(D.) kasinganak ‘the same age, age mate’.

(N.) serrated edges (of cloth). Simon de Andas, a
famous Spaniard who once transferred the seat of
Spanish government to Bacolor.

(N.) female sexual organs. antak-ne-da-mu [an
indecent curse]. (D.) mayantak ‘sexually attractive
(female)’.

(N.) anti-ra’bis, anti-te-tanus ‘injections to prevent
rabies, tetanus’.

(Subcombiner) later, and then, so.
[often combined with uling, as: anyaq, e ko bisang
mamangan king kekami uling ing asan mi tuyuq.
‘And so that’s why you don’t want to eat at our
house because our main course is dried fish’].

(Prep.) up to, until.
(N.) angganan ‘boundary’.
(V.) man-angga ‘reach as far as, journey to’;
mipa-angga; mangayang-ganan.

(N.) mist, spray, blowing rain.
(V.) mamanggiq ‘it is raining and blowing’.

(N.) wind.
(V.) mamangin ‘the wind is blowing’; angin-an,
in-angin ‘held in the wind’; payangin,
magpayangin, magpakayangin.
(D.) mayangin ‘windy (season, people)’.

(N.) narra, a kind of tree. Apalit, a town in
Pampanga.
10

(N.) a vegetable, ampalaya.
[metaphorically] a person with a sour disposition.

(N.) bait.
(V.) apan-an ‘bait something’; man-apan ‘put out
bait’; maipanapan ‘bait each other’; pan-apan-an.

(N.) lime (calcium oxide); used in making cement;
and as a component of the betel-chew.

(N.) fire, flame, spark.
(V.) mamapi’q ‘is sparking, is on fire’.

(N.) beach [probably a recent borrowing; more
commonly: bebe-dagat].

(N.) a kind of fish, expensive and considered quite
a delicacy.

(N.) grandparent, especially grandmother. As a
term of address, apu is used for grandfather and
grandmother; as a term of reference, usually it is
restricted to grandmother, with ingkong being
used for grandfather. With saints’ names, as: Apu
Lusya ‘Saint Lucy’.

See na:pun ‘yesterday’; gatpanapun ‘afternoon’;
patinga’pun ‘the whole day’.

(N/V/St.) imitation, similarity. Apus mu ku kaya.
‘You are making me look like him’. pa:yapus; see
-kyapus.

(V.) mag-aral ‘study, go to school’. manig-aral
[distributive]; papag-aral ‘be sent to school’.
(N.) panig-aral-an; pag-aral-an ‘lesson’.

(N.) arap/arapa’n ‘the front’.
(D.) maka-arap; miaraparap ‘be situated in front’.

(D.) finished. mayari ‘finished’; mayayari.
(V.) ari-an ‘finish something’; man-ariq
‘(something) happened’.

(N.) things customarily disapproved; statements of
customary disapproval.

(N.) 1. fish. 2. viand, i.e., food eaten with rice.
(V.) asan-an, in-asan, as: nanung inasan yu? ‘What
did you eat with your rice?’.

(N.) spouse; [metaphor] ‘one of a pair, like mortar
and pestle’, tala-asawa ‘a married person’.
(V.) mag-asawa ‘get married’; mang-asawa ‘[old]
arrange marriage’, ‘[new] have sexual
intercourse’; paki-asawa ‘have someone married
to someone else’; pang-asawa-n ‘rape someone’;
mi-asawa ‘be married’.

(N.) salt; [metaphor] ‘brains, cleverness’.
(V.) asin-an ‘to salt something’. payasin,
paki-asinan, man-asin, apa-yasin, ayasinan
‘unintentionally salted’.

(N.) light from a heavenly body; see saslag.
aslagan ‘place where the sun rises, east’.

(N.) vinegar.
(D.) maslam ‘sour’.
(V.) aslam-an ‘add vinegar to something’;
pan-aslam ‘use something to sour’.

(N.) stake.
(V.) man-astaka ‘place stakes’; astak-an ‘bound
with stakes’.

(N.) a frightening spirit creature, half-human,
half-bird, vampire-like, said to prey on corpses and
unborn children.
(V.) aswang-an, inaswangan ‘made victim by an
aswang’.

(N.) 1. comb.
2. harrow.
(V.) man-aswe ‘use a harrow. aswe-n ‘comb (hair)‘;
payaswe ‘have hair combed by another’.

(Cocombiner) ‘and’.
Sometimes ‘that’, as: kapna mu at bala mu ‘it’s
good that you know it’.

(V.) escort away from home to another place.
mamatad, i (h) atad, paki-atad.
(N.) pamatad-oras ‘pastime’.

(N.) attack, heart-attack, stroke.
(D.) me-atake ‘victimized by stroke’.

(Nu.) three.
pangatlu ‘third’; makatatlu ‘third time’; titlu-titlu
‘three-by-three’. atlung-ari 1. Feast of Three
Kings; 2. a constellation.

(V.) throw; itca ‘threw’.
makayatcaq [ability]; atca-nan ‘throw something
to somebody’; mipayatca; ayatca.
(N). pa:manatcaq ‘pitching style’; piyatcanan
‘place something was thrown’.
(V.) to the back, rear; retrogress. see qatras.

(N.) older sister.
Also used as a term of polite address to women,
as: Atsing Edad, Atsing Son.

(N.) flatulence.
(V.) atutan ‘affect another with one’s flatulence’.
(N.) a large bird of prey, crow or hawk.

(N.) air.
(D.) de-ayri ‘works by means of air’.

(V.) agree with, go along with.
ayun-an, pa-ayun-an, maki-ayun.

(N.) spider.
babagwaq singgagatu, babagwang bale,
babagwang tanaman.

(N.) low place, underneath; old name of the
town now called Lubao.
(V.) baba’q, be:baq ‘lower, put down’; disclose,
set forth; i-babaq ‘lower something’; mag-baba
‘go down’; paba-ban ‘have something brought
down’; ababaq, apababan.

(N.) woman; (pl.) ba:bai. binabai ‘common-law
wife’; binabai ‘girlhood’.
(V.) mambabai/magbabai ‘pursuing women’.

(N.) pig. babing-diku’t ‘wild pig’.
(D.) bina’biq ‘careless’.
(V.) mag-binabiq ‘be careless, act like a pig’.

(V.) get dressed; see piblas. mi-bablas ‘be
dressed’; pi-bablas-an ‘dress someone else’.

(N., Prep.) up, upstairs, above.
(V.) mag-babo, magpababo ‘go up’; papababo
‘put something on top’; makapagpababo ‘able
to go on top’.
(D.) mababo ‘on top, above’; maka-babo
‘leading (in election)’; maba’-bo-pa’liq ‘easily
angered’.

(N.) packed lunch, food carried along when on
a trip.
(V.) mag-baka’l ‘carry one’s lunch’; abakalan
‘able to carry something’.

(N.) mark, sign, indication.
(V.) babakas, mamakas ‘make marks’; bakasan,
bekasan ‘mark something’; pabakas ‘have
something marked’.

(N.) scar, scab, peeling skin.
(V.) mangabakbak, magpabakbak, mipamakbak
‘peel off something’.
(D.) mabakbak.

(N.) yoke. makabakle ‘warp, or woof, in
weaving’.
(V.) bakle, bikle ‘put something across
something else’.
(D.) makabakle ‘out of condition, in a bad
mood’.

(N.) oar, paddle.
(V.) babakse, mamakse ‘row, paddle’,
makapamakse ‘be able to paddle’; makibakse
‘paddle with others’.

(N.) Bacolor, a town in Pampanga.
makabakulud ‘plain, plateau, high level rocky
place’.

(V.) mag-bakwe’ ‘smoke with burning part of
cigarette or cigar inside mouth’; babakwe.

(N.) pulp, the part of the sugarcane which is
discarded after milling; sawdust.

(D.) matching, compatible.
(V.) bagay-an ‘match something to something
else’.
(N.) thing, object, affair. bage-ba’ge ‘small
things, details’.

(N.) railroad car. bagune’ru ‘conductor’.
(V.) pa:bagun ‘use a railroad car to carry’.

(N.) tropical storm, typhoon. pabagyu ‘a
showoff’.
(V.) babagyu ‘a typhoon is blowing’.

(N.) bachelor, unmarried male [also used of
young male carabao]. mamayintau ‘one who is
being a bachelor.

(N.) responsibility, warning, matter, concern
as: ika ing ba:laq ‘you are in charge, it’s up to
you, you decide’. e ba:laq ‘it doesn’t matter.
(V.) bala-an, babalan, bebalan ‘warn someone
about something’; paba:laq ‘give one
responsibility’; panibalaq.
(N.) kapama:lan ‘the government’.

[idiomatic expression–inflection highly
limited].
bala’ mu ‘you would think; it seems;
apparently’. bala’ ku ‘I think so; it seems so to
me’.

(V.) bala’ba:n ‘cut something down’. be:la’baq,
mamalabaq, pabalabaq, pamalaban.

(V.) magpabala’g ‘drop out’; maka-bala’g ‘fall
accidentally’; manga-bala’g ‘dropping
repeatedly’; pa:-balag ‘caused to drop’; a:balag
‘dropped’; a:pabala’g ‘had an abortion,
miscarriage’.
(D.) ma-balag ‘dropped’.

(N.) father of a married child as he stands
related to the father of his child’s spouse.
mibalai ‘be related as balai’.
(V.) mamalai ‘arrange a marriage’; abalai ‘be
made balai of someone’.

(N.) a kind of insect said to be destructive to
coconut trees.

(N.) clay pot, used to cook viands.
[also used as a nickname].

(N.) framework.
(V.) babalangkas, mamalangkas ‘construct’;
balangkasan, belangkas, pa:balangkas,
magpabalangkas, paki-balangkas, abalangkas,
apabalangkas.
(D.) mabalangkas.

(N.) a grass or reed which grows near river
banks and is used to weave mats and hats.

(N.) sand.
Also the name of a barrio of Bacolor.
(V.) ma:malasmala’s ‘feels sandy’.

(N.) eggplant.
[metaphor] penis.
(V.) mamalase’nas [with the metaphorical
sense]
22

(N.) ‘blow-out’–a party where one who has
come on some good fortune pays all the
expenses.
(V.) mamala’tuq.

(N.) shattered pieces. kabalbal; pibalbalan ‘the
pieces left intact when something has
shattered’.
(V.) mangabalbal, makabalbal, makibalbal,
pakibalbal, pabalbal, abalbal, apabalbal.
(D.) mabalbal.

(N.) beard. pekabalbas ‘a fake beard’.
(D.) mabalbas ‘bearded’; balbasan ‘bearded’.
(V.) mamalbas ‘shave self’; magpabalbas ‘get
shaved’; mangabalbasan ‘let beard grow’;
makapamalbas; pa-pagbalbasan ‘tell someone
to get a shave’.

(D.) crippled, lame.
(V.) mangabaldadu, makapagbaldadu,
makibaldadu, pa:baldadu, apabaldadu.

(V.) fall down.
bildug; a:baldug ‘fell accidentally’; ke:baldug
‘caused to fall’; pa:baldug ‘cause to fall;
translate’; magpabaldug ‘let self drop behind
others’.
(N.) kabaldugan ‘meaning’; baldugan-panyuq
‘drop-the-handerchief’.
23

(N.) a lending system, called ‘five-six’; 20%
interest, payment daily.
(V.) mamaldug.

(N.) house.
makibale’ ‘house owner, housewife’;
kasi’ping-bale’ ‘neighbor’; balebalayan
‘play-house’.

(N.) town.
kabalen ‘townmate’; kabalenan ‘the town
proper’; me:malen ‘the townspeople’;
mibalenbalen ‘related to each other as from
the same town’.
(D.) pambalen ‘civic’.
(N.) a woven shopping bag or basket.

(V.) mag-ba’lik ‘return’; i-balik ‘return
something’; balikan ‘return to somewhere’;
pabalikan ‘return something’.
(N.) kabalik ‘opposite, opponent’. kabalikan
‘reverse’.

(D.) crooked, twisted, incorrect. balidbali’d
‘ungrammatical speech’.
(N.) kabalidbalid ‘errors in grammar’.

(D./St.) backwards. mabaligtad, makabaligtad.
(N.) baligta’rin ‘reversible cloth, political
turncoat, one who speaks ambiguously’.
(V.) magbaligtad ‘tumble backwards’.
pabaligtad, pakibaligtad, ke:baligtad,
a:baligtad, mibaligtad. i-baligtad ‘reverse
something, turn something inside-out’.

(N.) a person who ‘backbites’, i.e., says nice
things in your presence but derogates you in
your absence. A somewhat sour, segmented
fruit [some speakers say this is not
Kapampangan but Tagalog–see taranatiq].

(N.) edge of ear.
(V.) balimbinga’n ‘to flick edge of another’s ear,
as parents mildly punish children’.

(N.) level, grade, rung of a ladder.
(V.) mamalitang ‘repair or install ladder rungs’.

(N.) a species of tree, said to be a favored
place of spirits.
A barrio of San Fernando.

(N.) a medicinal concoction, made from boiling
gizzard of duck or chicken in salt and water.
Said to be a remedy for appendicitis.

(N.) balm. balsame’ru/mambalsamu
‘embalmer’.
(V.) balsamwan ‘to embalm someone’;
panambalsamwan.
(D.) mabalsamu ‘embalmed’.

(N.) knowledge. mikibaluq, makibaluq ‘people
who know’.
(V.) balwan, belwan ‘know something’; pabaluq
‘inform; ipabaluq; a:baluq ‘informed’; tabaluq
‘don’t know’.

(V.) mamaltang ‘take a shortcut’.
makapamaltang ‘able to be shortened’.
(N.) pa:mamaltang ‘shortcut, the taking of a
shortcut’; baltanga’n ‘a shortcut’.

(N.) cashew (‘Queen of the fruits, because it
sits on a throne’).

(D.) bent, curled up.
makabaluktut ‘in a bent position’; mibaluktut
‘got bent’.
(V.) magbaluktut, pa:baluktut, pamaluktut,
a:baluktut, makibaluktut, pakibaluktut.

(N.) Negrito [generally used as a term of
opprobrium].

(N.) ear(s); bottom of the macopa fruit.
(V.) balugbuga’n ‘hit in the ear’.

(V.) babalusbus winnow (rice).
mamalusbus, pa:balusbus, pakibalusbus,
a:balusbus.
2. to mull over the meaning of something.

(V.) ba’lut, ibalut ‘wrap something’.
magpabalut ‘have someone wrap’; makibalut,
pakibalut, a:balut, mibalut.
(D.) mabalut, makabalut.
(N.) balutan ‘thing wrapped’; pipag-balutan
‘thing used to wrap’.
26

(N.) aged but unhatched duck egg eaten as a
delicacy, snack.

(D.) holy, sacred.
Ding Banal a Kasulatan ‘The Holy Scriptures’.
(V.) magpakabanal ‘be holy, pretend to be holy,
make oneself holy’.

(N.) musical band.
(D.) mikiba’nda ‘be in possession of a band’.

(Prep.) proceeding, towards.
(V.) magbanda ‘go towards’; ibanda ‘move
something’; a:banda ‘something can be
moved’l.
(D.) makabanda ‘situated towards’.
(N.) a woven basket, large, with handles.

(N.) wealth, possessions. mikibandi ‘owner’;
ingat-bandi ‘treasurer’; pibandian
‘possessions’.
(V.) pabandi ‘possess, obtain’; pakibandi.
(D.) mabandi ‘owning, rich’; peka-mabandi
‘richest’.

(N.) musical combo, usually guitar and violin,
sometimes accordion.

(N.) silt, erosion.
Name of a sitio in Bacolor.
(D.) mibabanlikan ‘silted over’.

(N.) alias, nickname.
(D.) famous.
(V.) bansagan, binsagan ‘nickname someone’.

(V.) guard, watch over. magbante, banten,
binte, pa:bante, makibante, pakibante, a:bante.
(N.) bante-plasdan ‘fishpond caretaker’;
bantayan ‘a watching place, waiting shed’.

(N.) wires used to brace nipa houses in
typhoons.
(V.) pa:banting ‘put up bracing wires’.
(D.) mabanting ‘braced’.

(N.) a furled leaf.
suman-ba’nus ‘a rice delicacy of the suman
type, wrapped in banus’.

(N.) year; sky; heaven.
pabanwa ‘a whole year, first year’.
(D.) banwaqan ‘annually’; banwa-banwa
‘annua1ly’.
(V.) magpabanwa ‘going on one year’.

(N.) jar made of clay, often for holding drinking
water.

(V.) divide, split.
babangal, binangal; bangalan; magpa-bangal;
pabangal; pa:mangal; makibangal; pakibangal.
(N.) kabangal ‘a piece’; pa:mamangal
‘division’.
(D.) mabangal.

(N.) a woven coverless basket, like a salikap
but with rounded corners.

(N.) a tool–long pole with curved metal
blade–used for cutting bamboo.
(V.) bangkuran ‘cut with bangkud’;
pa:bangkud, pakibangkud, a:bangkud.
(D.) me:bangkud.

(N.) rice crust, the rice at the bottom of the
pot.
(V.) mamangiq.

(St./D.) mabangu’ngut ‘have a nightmare, be
affected by a seizure during
sleep. Sometimes fatal and said to be caused
by over-eating of rice. Old folks disapprove
discussing this’.

(N.) milk-fish.
bangusa’n ‘a disease of skin on face near
mouth, sign of a curse’. mestiso-bangus [used
to tease].

(N.) stud (male hog, goose, cow, horse,
carabao, human).

(D.) stuck, stopped up. mabaradu, mebaradu,
makabaradu.
(V.) magbaradu. baradwan, beradwan ‘stop
something up’.

(N.) balustrade, or the part of a wall with
balustrade and shutters.

(N.) gang, one’s group of intimates. kabarka’da
‘one related to speaker as member of same
gang’.
